English.lblWhatWasRevolutionAns:
The Romanian Revolution was very quick and filled
with confusion, and it only lasted for seven days. Most
of the country did not even know a revolution was 
happening until after it was over. The revolution occured
in 1989 and many Romanians continue to feel nostalgic
towards communism.
English.lblWorkAnsPolLong: Jobs were limited: Securitate, engineer, doctor, professor, factory worker, or, if skilled, a sportsman. Family pressure pushed for roles like lawyer, doctor, or pilot. Assignments were far from home, often in villages in the middle of nowhere, with no choice or prior knowledge of the destination.
English.lblWorkAns: "Who knows where in the country, but you had the job. Let's presume you finished medicine. You became a young doctor, but who knows where in a little village in Romania."
English.lblUniversityAnsPolLong: University was mostly for students to obtain technical degress that would help in industrialization, construction, education, and health. After graduating, they were sent to anywhere in the country where there was a need for 'repartisare.' University was especially attractive to young men because they could shorten their mandatory military service.
English.lblUniversityAns: "After finishing my studies, I would have been sent to go as a teacher somewhere in the countryside for a compulsatory partisanship."
English.lblUniversityQ: Why did people choose to go to university?
English.lblEmigrationAnsPolLong: Emigration was nearly impossible and trying to escape the country was met with rejection, arrest, and imprisonment. You could only leave if you were a sportsman or had special permission. You were forced to provide information upon your return.
English.lblEmigrationAns: "I became very attractive as a German-speaking student for the Securitate… they needed a translator to accompany a young secretary of the central committee of the young communists. One of their bosses got invited to a conference in West Germany and they selected me to be a translator... they were testing me. I then defected."
English.lblEmigrationQ: What was the punishment for trying to leave Romania?
English.lblYouthOrgAnsPolLong: Pioneers are a ranking in schools from 2nd-8th grade, which was indicated by wearing a red scarf. Many school children fought over having a rank in school because it gave more value to their lives.
English.lblYouthOrgQ: What did being a pioneer in grade school mean?
English.lblDemonstationAnsPolLong: Civilians were forced to attend Communist party festivities that promoted comunist ideologies and praising Nicolae Ceausescu. Consequences for not attending could include being fired from your job or harsh torture.
English.lblDemonstrationAns: "We didn't have TV, you know. It was only for two hours during the evening when the whole program was only about Ceausescu. It was nothing else."
English.lblMediaAnsPolLong: Books, movies, and news were available but all were censored to control information and prevent criticism of the regime. The role of the media was to spread state propaganda, convincing people that Ceausescu was a great leader and that life was better than it really was. Some Romanian and foreign media was sold in black markets.
English.lblMediaAns: "We didn't have TV, you know. It was only for two hours during the evening when the whole program was only about Ceausescu. It was nothing else."
English.lblMediaQ: What type of media was available?
English.lblRationAnsPolLong: Rations = fixed amount of goods that citizens are allowed to consume in times of shortages. Rations were placed on basic necessities like food, cooking oil, soaps, gasoline, electricity, and heating.
English.lblRationAns: "We have to deal with rations, because if we want to buy usual stuff like oil or gas or bread or meat or butter, we have to have the cards, the tickets for the rations."
English.lblChildhoodAnsPolLong: Many were protected by their parents but some still knew that the propaganda was lies. Children had to do chores, wait in the ration queues, and do homework in the dark. But, they still had hobbies and played with their friends. Some children lost their mothers due to illegal failed abortions.
English.lblChildhoodAns: "Parents fought to create some sense of normalcy in the midst of the disaster that was reality."
English.lblChildhoodQ: What was it like to be a child during this period?
English.lblFoodAnsPolLong: Food was scarce and there was no variety in stores. Basic necessities were rationed and of much worse quality compared to today.
English.lblFoodAns: "Not because you didn't have money, but because you can not find other things."
English.lblSchoolAnsPolLong: School was very strict. The party wanted to demonstrate how educated and proper its citizens were - kids were even required to write in ink in a calligraphy style. All classrooms had a portrait of Ceausescu and students had to chant slogans about the Romanian Communist Party and how great Ceausescu is every day. There were lessons about the communist ideology and students were punished for not being able to recite Ceausescu's policies and speeches.
English.lblSchoolQ: How was learning in school different in this time?
English.lblDeportationAnsPolLong: The Securitate deported people that were perceived as dangerous to the communist party.
English.lblDeportationAns: "Young people that wrote we want food, freedom, and such on walls were seen as people who were dangerous against the regime and were put away."
English.lblPalaceAnsPolLong: Seven square kilometers of neighborhoods were destroyed to make room for the Palace of the People. Part of the money for this project came for relief funds for earthquake victims.
English.lblPalaceQ: What was the Palace of the People built for?
English.lblPalaceAns: "The actual Romania didn't exist for me anymore. And it didn't exist also because the neighborhood where I lived, where I was born, my house, my street, my neighborhood was pulled down."
English.lblFearAnsPolLong: People living under communism felt a mix of fear, anger, frustration, and hopelessness. Fear came from constantly being watched and reported. Frustration came from extreme shortages and harsh rules. Deep inside, many people still held onto hope. They dreamed  of freedom and a better life.
English.lblFearQ: What emotions did people feel while living under communism?
English.lblFearAns: "We thought that our destiny was completely destroyed but we did not complain. Just fought."
English.lblReligionAnsPolLong: Those who came from religous families were said to have unhealthy origins. Students that went to church on Sundays could be punished by their teachers and could prevent them from having other opportunities such as getting a university.
English.lblReligionQ: How did people follow their faith?
English.lblReligionAns: "My father was a priest which was an unhealthy origin."
English.lblExportsAnsPolLong: Romania exported a lot of products, especially during the 1980s, to pay off foreign debts. These included food like grains, meat, and oil, machinery, textiles, and cars. The state sent loads of resources to other countries while Romanians at home faced extreme shortages and empty shelves.
English.lblExportsAns: "The economy was going so badly due to Ceauşescu's poor leadership and idiotic investments in heavy industries… unsustainable, no raw materials, no energy, not enough of a work force."
English.lblInfluenceAnsPolLong: No relationships with foreigners were allowed unless they were reported and approved by the party. Romanians were harshly limited on places they could travel to and it was hard to obtain visas for travel.
English.lblInfluenceQ: How did Romanian's interact with people in foreign countries?
English.lblInfluenceAns: "It was not easy to travel and we could not consume foreign media."
English.lblPossesionsAnsPolLong: They were often confiscated, controlled, or heavily monitored. Items that the Securitate labeled as "Western" or anti-regime were destroyed or hidden. The state could seize property whenever they wanted, and many people lived in fear of losing their belongings simply is they were perceived as being disloyal.
English.lblPossesionsQ: What happened to people's private posessions?
English.lblPossesionsAns: "When the communists came, they had to give it away just like that. Everything that they had - cows, sheep, horses - it wasn't theirs. It was the government's."
English.lblLanguageAnsPolLong: Party figures spoke in a rigid, artifical style like "wooden language." It was a soulless way of talking that erased people's thoughts and expression. Words became like weapons of control and submission.
English.lblLanguageQ: How did politicians speak during the time?
English.lblPropogandaAnsPolLong: Propaganda: newspapers, TV, posters, and school lessons to brainwash people's thoughts and speech to maintain their loyalty. The PAD controlled all information and media, creating endless praise for Ceausescu and promoting socialist ideals through propaganda. This department limited cultural diversity in the country.
English.lblPropogandaQ: What was the role of the Propaganda & Agitation Department?
English.lblPropogandaAns: "The Securitate’s weapon was propaganda. The old Securitate are good at changing history even now, contributing to today’s nostalgia."
English.lblConsequencesAnsPolLong: Political detainees were people that the Securitate perceived as being threats to the regime or expressing any opposition to its ideology. They faced discrimination, surveillance, loss of jobs, and sometimes even imprisonment.
English.lblConsequencesQ: What happened to political detainees and their families?
English.lblConsequencesAns: "Two other women were in the same cell, but not political prisoners, were there for  “common” reasons. One was selling medicine illegal, and the other was doing illegal abortions."
English.lblSecuritateAnsPolLong: The Securitate used informants as snitches on people, followed people around, intercepted mail, and tapped phones. Any person, including children, could be coerced to be an informant to the Securitate. If you were an informant, there were benefits like food tickets, better jobs, etc.
English.lblSecuritateQ: What was the main tool of oppression?
English.lblSecuritateAns: "I felt extremely cornered… the Securitate were testing me."
